title: 1120-E
statement: E. The very same Munchhausentime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputA positive integer $$$a$$$ is given. Baron Munchausen claims that he knows such a positive integer $$$n$$$ that if one multiplies $$$n$$$ by $$$a$$$, the sum of its digits decreases $$$a$$$ times. In other words, $$$S(an) = S(n)/a$$$, where $$$S(x)$$$ denotes the sum of digits of the number $$$x$$$.Find out if what Baron told can be true.InputThe only line contains a single integer $$$a$$$ ($$$2 \\le a \\le 10^3$$$).OutputIf there is no such number $$$n$$$, print $$$-1$$$.Otherwise print any appropriate positive integer $$$n$$$. Your number must not consist of more than $$$5\\cdot10^5$$$ digits. We can show that under given constraints either there is no answer, or there is an answer no longer than $$$5\\cdot10^5$$$ digits.ExamplesInput2Output6Input3Output6669Input10Output-1

processed.result:
You are given a positive integer $a$. Determine if there exists a positive integer $n$ such that the sum of the digits of $an$ is equal to the sum of the digits of $n$ divided by $a$. 

If such an integer $n$ exists, print it. Otherwise, print $-1$. 

The number $n$ should not have more than 500,000 digits.

Given a number, find another number that when multiplied by the first number, results in a product where the sum of the digits of the product is  $1/a$ times the sum of the digits of the second number. If no such number exists, output -1.
